author: MajorJin
body:
I think a better question would be, what is wrong with our hiring and employment practices? 

For perspective, I am an operations manager for a Fortune 500 company, and I oversee around 300-350 employees on average who make between $30-40/hr with good benefits. 

Is the problem that corporations are holding too close to archaic wage, hiring, and management practices? Or is the real problem that "Working Class" people are fed up with either underpaid, undervalued, or having their sense of job security taken away. I mean honestly how dare the working class want something better. 

Most companies have not worked to create good company cultures. What I have seen over my working career in many industries is that employees are often undervalued by their managers and companies. Employees are not given clear paths for progression and have been beaten down with wage stagnation to protect and promote stock growth. Even at $40/hr our attrition rates are getting rough due to labor and wage practices.

Current hiring practices are also to blame. Why do we have three interviews for a job that pays minimum wage? If you think that is bad, try applying for white collar or skilled jobs, where it takes not only multiple interviews, but MONTHS of waiting to find out if you got the job or not. Automated software is also to blame. It often removes dozens of valid candidates from the hiring lists in the attempt to find "perfect" candidates. 

Then comes 2020. Large sectors of the economy are labeled "non-essential" and are told to go home. In an instant, millions of people were told they are not an important part of the economy and their jobs could be taken away arbitrarily thus reducing their feelings of job security. 

All of these factors and more have contributed to a massive amount of unfilled jobs. HR departments won't scrap non-working hiring practices, CEO's won't raise wages to attract talent, and our Government has yet make a concerted effort to regain public trust. 

Do I feel annoyed that people took the last few months to evaluate their participation in the workforce and aren't at Starbucks filling my order? Or do I understand that many took the time to create financial stability in other sectors and leave jobs where they were either undervalued, underpaid, or the government took their sense of job security?

 I do not feel sorry for companies that fail to recognize a shift in "working class" values. 

Also, for the person who decided to make money off of investing and replaced their income, Good for you! I am glad you found a way to make income that you enjoy.

author: StraightDollar
body:
Everyone has known how bad Facebook is for years. Literally years. There has been CONSTANT negative press against Facebook since IPO. There has been a major blockbuster documenting what a weird cunt Zuck is. And time after time the FUD dissipates, there is zero new regulation, FB revenue and EBITDA flies up and we all move on with our lives 

The reality with FB is that it is a business that is approaching the limit of the organic growth on its core business, is absolutely flush with cash, and is looking for the next big revenue driver to make it a 2tn company. Zuck believes it is the metaverse - that is not just rhetoric (you don’t hire 10,000 people to build it on a whim)

The big (and only) question you have to answer as a prospective investor is whether you agree with Zuck that meta is the next big thing or not

author: Dry_Dog_698
body:
BABA’s valuation at $300 was based in large part on its 33% ownership of ANT.

When ANT was ruined BABA lost 20% of its value.  

Since then the CCP and Xi has come out against the consumer internet retail business model.  They have come out against video games.  They have come out against online education.  And it is believed - international investing.

You have a powerful central government coming out against the central business mode of big Chinese tech companies, that’s why people are leaving the trade.

BABA was last permanently below $150 in 2017.  We don’t have selling pressure from traders or sector ETFs anymore.  This is an unwinding of long term investors.

Finally: no one is 100% that the founder is even still alive.  Jack Ma has been sighted by humanity 6 times since Xi went to pound town and companies related to Ma lost a half trillion in market value.  The most verifiable by the west?  A Japanese billionaire claims that he and Jack Ma text every now and again, that Jack Ma has taken up painting, and the pictures he has seen are pretty good.

author: jsntx
body:
If clearinghouses and brokers can legally restrict a targeted group of non-institutional investors from making one side of the trade at a critical moment, it doesn't matter what the report says. It will say whatever it needs to say.

Whether we believe in conspiracies or not, the markets are arguably not the same for regular investors. We are trying to argue a condition for which we don't have reliable sources. So I would stick to the business potential and what it's in the best interest to me individually; which is to hold.

author: lvdown
body:
When the price hit 18.00 your sell order was then automatically placed. But in the few seconds it took to place and fill your order the price had crashed to 8.60. You got filled at 8.60. 

Set a limit order stop loss next time not a market order stop loss. This will prevent this from happening but your shares would not be sold at all. In the limit order case it would place your sell order at $18.00 when the price hits $18.00. The order will never fill because the price went below 18. The downside to this is that the price could have gone down further from $8.60 and you would still be holding.

author: attorneyatslaw
body: Hertz paid everyone in full because it turned out they weren't really bankrupt at all, so it wasnt really a restructuring of debt.   They filed because the market for used cars crashed at the beginning of Covid, so they got margin called on their credit lines (secured by their rental cars).  However, the used car market then spiked to all time highs, so the margin calls went away and they were able to go back to business as usual.  Hertz usually buys around 500,000 cars a year.  They just are moving their purchases from other brands to Tesla.

author: Mittenwald
body: We have a massive shortage of biotech workers in San Diego. My company is struggling to hire. When they lost out on a candidate to a startup our vice president told my co-worker he didn't understand why. She told him it's about money. And they offered much more plus stocks. Our executive team isn't getting the message that they need to raise wages. I've also been hearing our bonuses might not be anything this year because of one failed project. We all are be hounded by recruiters. Eventually the offers will be too good to pass up. Funny how companies love capitalism when it makes them profits but hate it when the workers can actually utilize it.

author: squench2000
body:
For those wondering what to make of these 2 figures:

If you see a median and mean far apart like this, it means that outliers are pulling the mean away from center (in this case, upwards by high NW outliers), and that the median is a better representation of true central tendency.

author: ajmartin527
body:
When I lived in vegas one of my clients owned an auto group that included a Rolls Royce/Bentley/Aston dealership. He said Floyd used to come in and buy his cars with cash. The first time it happened he bought multiple cars at once and Floyd’s bag man handed the owner a giant sack of cash and he was just stunned. He didn’t really have a workflow for taking multiple hundreds of thousands in cash as payment. Wasn’t sure how to count it or anything either and had to hire extra security to travel with it to deposit and shit.

Floyd has bought tons of cars from him since and it’s always a bag of cash. Funny to hear him talk about it because the dude now sells Ferrari’s and Lambos too and no one else has ever paid cash in physical bills before, they usually just wire transfer it.

Edit: also, Floyd only buys/drives white cars in Vegas. Black in California I believe. He sticks with one color for each of the states he has houses in lol such a dickhead but it’s hilarious.

author: not_creative1
body:
It will move to india and m Vietnam.


India is now pumping money into infrastructure. They just approved a plan to spend $1.3 trillion over next 10 years on domestic infrastructure. That’s a fuckton of money. Especially in India. They are on a construction spree. 60% of all highways existing in the country today was built in the last 10 years.

They are throwing tax breaks at companies that are moving manufacturing to the country. Already something like 20% of all iPhones sold worldwide are made in india. It’s only going to increase.


The fundamental problem of high labor costs in the west is not going away anytime soon. Especially now with worker shortages, talks about minimum wage hikes.

author: Warren_Guh_Buffet
body: Dude BABA was Xi trying to screaw Ma. It had nothing to do with America or politics, dude stop with the conspiracy theories. BABA being a $150 stock today is also because of uncertainty. No one in Wallstreet knows if Xi will simply break up the company.
